promptImprover.title: The Prompt Improver: Because "Make it cool" is a Bad Brief (for AI, Too).
promptImprover.description:
Asking an AI for 'something about AI' is like getting a client brief that just says, 'We want it to go viral.' You'll get something, but it's probably not what you wanted.

This tool is your built-in creative director. It won't let you start with a bad brief. It asks you the annoying-but-necessary questions first: 'Who is this for?' 'What's the tone?' 'What's the one thing you want them to remember?' It turns your vague idea into a brief so sharp, the AI can't help but nail it.

promptImprover.howItWorksDesc: This AI 'brain' powers the Prompt Improver. This System Instruction guides the AI to act as a helpful collaborator.

heroGemWizard.title: Build Your AI Specialist (And stop getting "As a large language model..." answers)
heroGemWizard.introTitle: We've all been there. You ask a generic AI for your client's specific tone-of-voice, and it gives you a lecture on "the importance of branding." Let's fix that.
heroGemWizard.introPara1: Stop repeating the brief. Train your AI once on its job, personality, and rules. No more re-explaining—just ask and get work that's actually on-brief.
heroGemWizard.introPara2: Get expert results, not guesses. A generic AI is a jack-of-all-trades. This is a master of one: your brand. It uses your files to give expert advice, not a summary of the internet.
heroGemWizard.introPara3: Make it actually useful. Plan campaigns, draft emails in your style, analyze competitor research—with an AI that finally understands your world.
heroGemWizard.readyCTA: Ready? Pick your new 'team member' below and let's build. 👇
heroGemWizard.blueprint1Desc: Your on-demand researcher. Upload market research, notes, or product manuals, and it will answer complex questions based only on that knowledge.
heroGemWizard.blueprint2Desc: Your personal brand guardian. Upload your style guide, past emails, or writing examples, and it will rewrite any text to be perfectly on-brand.
heroGemWizard.blueprint3Desc: Your creative sparring partner. Feed it your creative briefs, half-baked ideas, or past campaigns, and it will help you generate new blog posts, ad copy, or social media angles.
heroGemWizard.blueprint4Desc: Your personal life-assistant. (Because even creatives need to plan groceries sometimes). Upload recipes, travel plans, or notes, and it helps you organize your life outside of work.
heroGemWizard.blueprint5Desc: A developer's best friend. Feed it API documentation, codebases, or data schemas to get quick, context-aware help with coding, debugging, or data analysis.
heroGemWizard.blueprint6Desc: Your secret weapon. Upload market research, competitor reports, or your business plan, and it will help you identify new opportunities, spot risks, and build strategies.

notebookLM.title: NotebookLM: The "One-Deck-to-Rule-Them-All" Tool
notebookLM.intro:
You know the drill. You finish the big research report. Then the CEO asks for a one-page summary. The CMO wants a 10-slide deck. And the creative team just wants the key insights for a brief.

Stop the copy-paste nightmare.
notebookLM.centralBrainTitle: The Central Brain for Your Knowledge
notebookLM.centralBrainDesc: Stop reformatting the same deck five times. NotebookLM transforms how you share knowledge. Just dump all your sources—transcripts, PDFs, decks, links—into one central 'brain' and ask it to generate exactly what each person needs. One source of truth, infinite formats. Get your week back.
notebookLM.step1Desc: Transcripts, PDFs, links, spreadsheets—every data source goes into one Notebook. Stop organizing upfront.
notebookLM.step2Desc: It ingests all sources and becomes your knowledge base—aware of relationships, contradictions, and insights.
notebookLM.step3Desc: Ask it to generate a CEO brief, a CMO deck, or an action plan—each stakeholder gets the exact format they need, instantly.
notebookLM.workflowTitle: The Workflow Visualized: From Rework to Results
notebookLM.trustTitle: The Trust Factor (AKA: "Where did you get that number?")
notebookLM.trustDesc: This is the feature that saves you in a client meeting. When your CEO asks, "Where does that projection come from?", NotebookLM cites the exact document. When your client questions a recommendation, you can point to the research it's based on. It's not a 'black box' guess; it's your own research, just smarter.
notebookLM.tryItTitle: Try It: The Stakeholder Perspective Generator
notebookLM.tryItDesc: Use the prompts below to see how the same "central brain" can serve completely different needs.

flowVibe.title: Understanding Your New Powers: From 'Vibe' to 'Signal'
flowVibe.subtitle: The way we talk to AI is changing. Here's a no-nonsense guide.
flowVibe.intro: The way we interact with AI is evolving. We started with conversational 'Vibe Coding,' got confused by the term 'Flow Coding,' and are now moving towards a more precise and powerful method: 'Signal Coding.' This guide is designed to help you master this evolution.

vibe.title: 1. Vibe Coding (The "Director" 🎬)
vibe.description: Fast, creative, and conversational. This is about giving the AI a general direction and iterating based on its output. It's like directing an actor—you provide the 'vibe' and see what you get back.
vibe.exampleText: on this page uses Vibe Coding. You give it a rough idea, and it directs the AI to refine it.

flow.title: 2. The "Flow Coding" Confusion
flow.description: The term 'Flow Coding' is ambiguous. It can mean being in 'the zone,' using a Git Flow, building with visual tools like Google Agentspace, or just 'going with the flow.' Because it lacks a clear definition, it's not a useful concept for building reliable AI systems. We need something more precise.
flow.conclusion: Conclusion: 'Signal Coding' is a more useful concept.'

signal.title: 3. Signal Coding (The "Architect" 📐)
signal.description: This is the evolution. Instead of a 'vibe,' you provide a clear, structured 'signal.' Signal Coding is about giving the AI precise, repeatable, and testable instructions to build reliable, production-ready systems. It's the language of AI architects.
signal.workflow: Structured instructions, system prompts, defined inputs/outputs.
signal.goal: Create predictable, scalable, and reliable AI applications.
signal.power: Enables agentic workflows and complex, multi-step tasks.
signal.exampleText: uses Signal Coding. Its two-step process with specific system instructions is a clear 'signal' for a predictable outcome.

promptImproverHeader.title: Unlock the Magic: How to Master Your Prompts 🚀
promptImproverHeader.paragraph1: LLMs are prediction engines. They generate the most likely next word based on your input. A vague prompt like "Tell me about AI" gives the model infinite directions to go—resulting in generic, unfocused output. But a specific prompt like "Write a 500-word blog post for developers explaining transformer architecture, using analogies and avoiding heavy math" gives the model clear guardrails.
promptImproverHeader.paragraph2: This tool uses a "baked-in" system instruction that acts as your expert Prompt Coach. Instead of teaching you theory, it asks the right questions to uncover gaps in your thinking—missing context, unclear objectives, format requirements—and collaboratively builds a better prompt with you through guided dialogue.

howItWasMade.title: A Workflow That Built This Website
howItWasMade.intro1: It started with a problem. I was brainstorming a presentation in my car (using Gemini Live) and had a thought: How many times have you seen a great demo, only to forget it seconds later?
howItWasMade.intro2: It's annoying. You see a practical tool, but the workflow—the how and why—is lost.
howItWasMade.intro3: I decided the presentation shouldn't just show my favorite AI workflows; it should be the workflow. This website is the result. It's a 'Gem' built using the very tools it demonstrates.
howItWasMade.intro4: Here is the 6-step process I used, evolving from a 'vibe' to a 'signal' to build this production-ready site.

step1.title: (The "What?")
step1.problem: What should this site be about? What workflows are actually useful? What's the best way to explain 'Vibe Coding' vs. 'Signal Coding'?
step1.action: I used the Deep Research prompt to analyze my presentation notes, past feedback, and articles on AI development.
step1.outcome: A clear content strategy. The research confirmed the 'Flow Coding' confusion and highlighted the need for a practical, hands-on site focused on 'Signal Coding' (i.e., building reliable, testable AI apps).

step2.title: (The "Brains")
step2.problem: How should the AI tools on this site, like the 'Prompt Improver,' actually behave? I needed to test the logic, fast.
step2.action: This was the 'Vibe Coding' phase. I used AI Studio as a web-based scratchpad. I could write and re-write system prompts, test different inputs, and tweak the AI's 'personality' and logic in seconds without any setup.
step2.outcome: A set of tested, functional, and powerful prompts that form the 'brains' of this site's tools.

step3.title: (The "Look")
step3.problem: The site needed a professional, responsive, and (most importantly) dark-mode-friendly UI, and I didn't want to spend days writing CSS.
step3.action: I wrote a single, detailed design prompt. I described the header, the two-column layout, the card-based design for each 'Gem,' and the color-themed code blocks.
step3.outcome: Stitch generated the entire front-end (HTML, CSS, and React components) in minutes. This wasn't a wireframe; it was 90% of the final code you're seeing now.

step4.title: (The "Glue")
step4.problem: How to connect the 'Brains' (from AI Studio) to the 'Look' (from Stitch) and build a real, testable application?
step4.action: This is where we shift from 'Vibe Coding' (prototyping) to 'Signal Coding' (building). The Gemini CLI is the bridge. It lets me use the exact same AI logic from AI Studio right inside my local terminal and development environment.
step4.outcome: A fully integrated, production-ready React application where the UI and AI logic work together seamlessly.

step5.title: (The "Launch")
step5.problem: How to get this site live and share it with you?
step5.action: I pushed the final application code to a GitHub repository. That repository is connected to Google Cloud Run, which automatically builds and deploys the site, making it live and scalable with a single command.

step6.title: (The "Refinement")
step6.problem: The content was functional, but did it resonate with a Dutch audience? Were the tone, style, and cultural references on point?
step6.action: I created a custom Gem trained on Dutch communication preferences and audience expectations. I fed it all the website copy and asked it to refine the language, tone, and messaging to better connect with this specific audience.
step6.outcome: Culturally-tuned copy that speaks directly to the Dutch market, making the site feel more personal and relevant.
